Atalyja (Lithuania)


The rain brings
The lunchtime of kings...
(Lithuanian childrenÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s song)

We first tried playing folk rock in spring 1998 in Kaunas city, at the Ãƒâ€šÃ‚Â«SuklegosÃƒâ€šÃ‚Â» international festival. We performed four Lithuanian folk songs then, enriching the sound with the kankles (a national string instrument), a fiddle, a base guitar and the Indian tabla. The idea was a success and it prompted the creation of the group Atalyja.
We founded the group in October 1998, and as soon as December we recorded a few songs that were repeatedly played on Lithuanian Radio. In April 1999 Atalyja gave a successful performance again at the Kaunas festival Ãƒâ€šÃ‚Â«SuklegosÃƒâ€šÃ‚Â».
We are also familiar with authentic folk music and we have prepared an authentic folk program that we performed in Warsaw and Torun (Poland) in June 1999. In spring 2000 we took part at the opening ceremony of Lithuanian National Archeological Museum. On May 19 Atalyja gave a concert in the sitting-hall of Vilnius TeachersÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢ House, presenting the groupÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s first twelve-song album. At the end of the concert we indeed evoked rain.
Atalyja is a Lithuanian dialect word meaning ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‹Å“approach of rainÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢. Our repertoire mainly embraces ancient Ãƒâ€šÃ‚Â«calendar songsÃƒâ€šÃ‚Â» and the sutartines (ancient Lithuanian polyphonic songs). We transform and interpret ancient Lithuanian folk music to make it sound modern. We also combine traditional folk means of expression (vocal and instruments) with the elements of rock and, occasionally, of Indian classical music. The features of jazzrock and funky music are also easy to discern in the arrangement of some songs.
